datafield.subfield: The Federal Theatre Project, created by the U.S. Works Progress Administration in 1935, was designed to conserve and develop the skills of theater workers, re-employ them on public relief, and to bring theater to thousands in the United States who had never before seen live theatrical performances. The collection includes correspondence, memoranda, play and radio scripts, reports, research studies, manuals, publications, bulletins, forms, lists, newspaper clippings, scrapbooks, charts, costume and set designs, blue-prints, posters, addressograph plates, photographs, negatives, slides, playbills, and other records documenting the activities of the Federal Theatre Project and its impact on all aspects of the theater.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The Federal Theatre Project, created by the U.S. Works Progress Administration in 1935, was designed to conserve and develop the skills of theater workers, re-employ them on public relief, and to bring theater to thousands in the United States who had never before seen live theatrical performances. The collection includes correspondence, memoranda, play and radio scripts, reports, research studies, manuals, publications, bulletins, forms, lists, newspaper clippings, scrapbooks, charts, costume and set designs, blue-prints, posters, addressograph plates, photographs, negatives, slides, playbills, and other records documenting the activities of the Federal Theatre Project and its impact on all aspects of the theater.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

controlaccess.head: Titles
controlaccess.title: New Deal Stage Selections from the Federal Theatre Project, 1935-1939.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Transfer and gift, U.S. Work Projects Administration, Washington office, and other, 1939-1946.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Federal Theatre Project Collection was processed by the Music Division of the Library of Congress. The Finding Aid was coded by Morgan Cundiff and other Music Division staff in 1995. In preparation for digitizing this finding aid and selected portions of the collection, minor changes were made in this inventory in 1997. The EAD coding was updated, revised and linked to the digital content by Michael Ferrando in 2004. In July 2011, interns working with Christopher Hartten re-housed portions of the large format materials. Hartten updated the finding aid to reflect the changes.

separatedmaterial.head: Other Repositories
separatedmaterial.p: Federal Theatre Project administrative materials at the National Archives and Records Administration, Record Group 69, include playscripts, play lists, production bulletins, set and costume designs, and photographic images.
George Mason University has acquired oral history interviews with, and donations from, persons originally associated with the Federal Theatre Project.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The Library of Congress Music Division holds the Federal Music Project Collection.
Materials from the Federal Arts Project are housed in the Prints and Photographs Division of the Library of Congress.
The Library of Congress Manuscript Division holds the United States Work Projects Administration Records.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright on the materials of the Federal Theatre Project Collection is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: container number, Federal Theatre Project Collection, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

eventgrp.event: Harry Hopkins,director of the WPA* and former head of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration (FERA), advocated a "free, adult, uncensored theatre" and announced the founding of the Federal Theatre Project (FTP).

The FTP was designed to re-employ theater workers on public relief; to conserve and develop the skills of administrators, clerical workers, writers, set and costume designers, directors, actors and actresses, technicians, and photographers; and to bring a theater, which would be national in scope and regional in emphasis, to thousands in the United States who had never before seen live theatrical performances.

chronitem.event: Hallie Flanagan,director of the Experimental Theatre, Vassar College, took the oath of office as the national director of the FTP. Headquarters were at the McLean mansion in Washington, D.C.

eventgrp.event: Under WPA's Federal Project Number One, $27 million was budgeted for unemployed artists, musicians, theatrical people and writers.
FTP units were set in operation and productions were planned throughout the United States.

chronitem.event: With 11,000 people on the payroll, production groups were operating in twenty-tow states and the weekly audience was 150,000.
Hallie Flanagan moved the headquarters from Washington, D.C., to New York City and assumed the directorship there in addition to the national directorship.
George Bernard Shaw and Eugene O'Neill released their plays to the FTP for nationwide production at a $50 rental rate.
Caravan theater toured the boroughs of New York City to present free entertainment to the public.

Since its inception, the FTP had played to audiences of 16 million in 28 states in 158 theaters. Notable productions included Macbeth, Murder in the Cathedral,
It Can't Happen Here, and Doctor Faustus.
Hallie Flanagan delivered a brief, outlining the progress of the FTP before the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Patents.
Planning began for a nationwide touring program in an effort to expand performances in outlying communities.

Noteworthy productions to date included One-Third of a Nation,
Prologue to Glory, a swing version of The Mikado, and Pinocchio.
A congressional joint resolution recommended that no funds be made available after June 30 for the operation of the FTP.

eventgrp.event: During its four-year existence, the FTP had mounted over 8,000 performances in thirty states and the District of Columbia.

Productions included classics, melodramas, comedies, circus performances, vaudeville, local pageants, foreign language plays, children's plays, dance productions, radio broadcasts, religious plays, Negro theater, and caravan plays.

Notable persons associated with the project included Bil Baird, Howard Bay, Eubie Blake,
Marc Blitzstein,
Joseph Cotten,
Katherine Dunham,
Abe Feder,
Arlene Francis,
Will Geer,
Paul Green,
John Houseman,
John Huston,
George Izenour,
Burt Lancaster,
Emmet Lavery,
Norman Lloyd, E.G. Marshall,
Arthur Miller,
Arthur Peterson,
John Randolph, Elmer Rice,
Betty Smith,
Virgil Thomson, and Orson Welles.

note.label: Note
note.p: Initially entitled the Works Progress Administration, the name was changed in 1939 to Work Projects Administration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Federal Theatre Project (FTP), an agency of the WPA from 1935 to 1939, provided work for thousands of unemployed persons in the theatrical profession. The project was an experiment which mirrored life in the Depression; depicted economic, political, and social problems; developed new audiences; provided opportunities for minorities; and laid the groundwork for much innovation in the theater. It was the first arts endeavor to be supported on a extensive scale by the U.S. government.

The records of the FTP span the years 1932-1943, with the bulk of the material concentrated in the years 1935-1939. Earlier and later dates appear in the collection. Some material from the Federal Emergency Relief Administration (FERA) and the Civil Works Administration (CWA) is dated as early as 1932. After the demise of the FTP in 1939, the Historical Record Survey (HRS) completed some research studies and inventories in 1942. A portion of the music file originally belonging to the Federal Music Project (FMP) records is dated 1943.

The materials in the FTP collection are of various types: correspondence, memoranda, reports, forms, lists, play and radio scripts, costume and set designs, posters, manuals, publications, bulletins, charts, blue-prints, research studies, addressograph plates, newspaper clippings, cards, photographs, negatives, slides, playbills, and scrapbooks. The collection is organized in four series: Administrative Records, Play Service and Research Records, Library Records, and Production Records.

The Administrative Records form the smallest section of the collection (the bulk of the FTP administrative materials is at the National Archives and Records Administration). This series provides background information on the FTP's organization, its policies and procedures, and personnel activity; its advertising and promotional plans; and the scope of its publications. A file on the WPA includes material relating to the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), the Federal Art Project (FAP), the Federal Music Project (FMP), the Federal Writers' Project (FWP), the Historical Records Survey (HRS), and other WPA activities. An extensive card file documents many of the activities of the FTP, and an administrative photographic prints and negatives file contains images of theater workers who qualified for work with the FTP.

The Play Service and Research Records contain much material from the National Service Bureau (NSB), the central record-keeping office of the project, which operated as a clearinghouse of information dealing with play service and research studies.

The Library Records are composed of material and information chiefly collected from sources outside of the FTP and maintained for use by the various units and regions, as well as for community, school, and church-related organizations.

The Production Records combine to form the largest part of the collection. These files relate directly to productions and planned productions. The material includes production bulletins, which were compiled following a production and contained pertinent information regarding that production; playbills, programs, and heralds; costume and set designs; posters and billboard sheets; photographs, negatives, and slides; music for productions; and some correspondence, reports, schedules, and scrapbooks.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Federal Theatre Project Collection
arrangement.p: The Federal Theatre Project Collection is organized in four series:

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, reports, inventories, reorganization plans, operations manuals, briefs, speeches, and administrative forms relating to the background, organization, policies, services, and procedures of the Federal Theatre Project (FTP). Included are chars and miscellany dealing with the administrative organization, weekly receipts, attendance records, and information for a House of Representatives committee.

arrangement.p: Chiefly chronologically arranged.

note.p: Includes: Dies Committee; Weekly attendance; Source of receipts; Miscellany

scopecontent.p: Correspondence; lists of personnel; hiring, transferring, and assigning of employees; biographical information; grievances; employment tests; daily time reports; and first-aid and accident reports. (Much of the material is from the New York, NY, Federal Theatre Photographic Division.)

arrangement.p: Chiefly chronologically arranged.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, advertising, mailing lists, audience research, photographic coverage, and promotional material, followed by addressograph plates and newspaper-clippings collages.

arrangement.p: Chiefly chronologically arranged.

scopecontent.p: Federal Theatre periodicals, reports, bulletins, play lists, songs, ballads, and catalogs, many with date and publication number.

arrangement.p: Chiefly chronologically arranged.

scopecontent.p: Administrative material including correspondence, speeches, reports, publications, publicity, and blank forms; activities and research studies of the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), Federal Art Project (FAP), Federal Music Project (FMP), Federal Writers' Project (FWP), Historical Records Survey (HRS); and WPA marionettes, radio, and theater research.

arrangement.p: Chiefly alphabetically arranged by subject and chronologically therein.

scopecontent.p: Sixty-five file sets of approximately 169,000 cards in three sizes: 3 by 5 inches, 4 by 6 inches, and 5 by 8 inches. The cards are of different colors, in some cases with colored metal signals, and are housed in original wooden and t\metal card drawers and cabinets. The information on the cards documents titles of plays, books, and magazines; FTP productions by title and region; plays loaned; classical and foreign play titles; bibliographies; requisitions for costumes, sound equipment, etc.; playreading active and inactive files; indexes to playscripts, books, Theatre Arts Monthly, living newspaper picture and text files, and photographic negatives and prints; royalty and non-royalty plays; music and songs for FTP productions; Regional Service Bureau of Los Angeles, Calif.; Talent Bureau casting file; actors' file; research; references to newspaper and magazine articles, speeches, lectures; Hallie Flanagan's lectures and articles; and mailing lists.

arrangement.p: Chiefly alphabetically arranged within the separate categories by personal name, subject or title.

scopecontent.p: General files of material collected by the FTP, including newspaper and magazine reviews and articles about dramas, books, and persons; correspondence, reprints, and reports regarding drama groups, labor groups, contests, marionettes, little theater groups; dramatic technique; bibliographies; published and unpublished studies and resources; short stories; and periodicals dealing with the theater.

arrangement.p: Chiefly alphabetically arranged by name, subject, or title.

scopecontent.p: Collection comprises over 2,500 play titles covering the classics, musicals, vaudeville scenarios, comedy sketches, living newspaper scripts, plays for children, and marionette scripts, by well-known or established authors as well as plays by unknown authors. Included are some directors' and prompters scripts, actors' sides (sheets, usually a half page, containing lines and cues for a single role), and varying versions of entire scripts or single acts. While most scripts are in English, there are some in French, German, Italian, Russian, Spanish, Swedish, and Yiddish. Some duplicate material.

arrangement.p: Chiefly alphabetically arranged by title.

scopecontent.p: About 2,000 radio scripts representing 150 series and single broadcasts presented by the Federal Theatre Radio Division. Most of the broadcasts aired in New York, NY. Other places include Los Angeles and San Francisco, Calif.; Oklahoma City, Okla.; Buffalo and Syracuse, NY.; and North Carolina. Information on some scripts includes standard voice directions; sound effects cues; information about the broadcasting station; and the date, time and length of the broadcasts which covered programs on art, history, music health, safety, science, children's shows, interviews with celebrities, plays, women, etc. Multiple folders indicate broadcasts within a series and also duplicate material.

arrangement.p: Chiefly alphabetically arranged by series and single broadcast title.

scopecontent.p: Lists compiled or collected from playreader reports and library resources for use by the various units and regions of the Federal Theatre and also made available to community organizations for help in choosing plays suitable for production. The lists, from single sheets to booklets, include plays that fall into sundry categories such as anti-war, Christmas pageants, classical drama, collective works, detective and mystery plays, one-act plays, Russian drama, youth, etc. Also included are publishers' catalogs and theater program lists. Some duplicate material.

arrangement.p: Arranged chiefly alphabetically by subject categories.

Some duplicate material.

scopecontent.p: Over 1,900 designs in color and black and white representing more than 160 productions in 13 cities. The majority of the designs were drawn for New York, NY, presentations. About 60 designers, many of whom signed their work, executed the drawings which range from rough sketches to detailed conceptions, done on scraps of paper, tracing paper, cardboard, and board. Actors' measurements and swatches of fabric accompany some designs. Drawings of stage properties are also included. When more than one design exists for a production, the number is indicated in parentheses if known.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by production title or subject. Stored in boxes and map file drawers.

scopecontent.p: Collection of approximately 1,000 posters of varying sizes of poster board done by the silk screen, offset lithography, and letterpress processes, as well as by hand. Produced by the Federal Art Project poster division and by artists employed directly by the FTP, the posters advertise over 500 productions in 91 cities in 24 states and the District of Columbia.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by production title or subject. Stored in map file drawers.

scopecontent.p: Collections of over 23,000 black and white photographs, grouped into nine subseries, documenting over 1,000 FTP productions in 67 cities in 27 states. Also included are portraits of actors, actresses, and well-known figures of the day, as well as prints of audiences, caravan theater, children's theater, circus, community theater presentation, marionette construction, office personnel, radio performances, research materials, sets, behind-the-scenes techniques, vaudeville, workshops, etc. Photograph albums, mural photographs, lobby cards, and collages complete this file. The prints, which are either 5 inches by 7 inches or 8 inches by 10 inches, with some oversized and mounted photographs, are stored in file cabinets and map file drawers. Duplicates are included.

arrangement.p: Chiefly alphabetically arranged within subseries by production title, state, and city; personal name; or subject.

arrangement.p: Chiefly alphabetically arranged by production title.

scopecontent.p: Collection of manuscript scores and parts, some complete; master sheets; printed music; FTP, FMP and WPA materials; audition music; and miscellany; divided into two subseries. The first, production-related music, includes regular and oversized sheets, scores, cue sheets, and some memoranda and reports relating to 153 FTP and FMP productions, planned productions, and presentations in 18 cities in 12 states. Arranged chiefly alphabetically by production title and then according to standard orchestral instrument order or by sequence of musical numbers. Included are variant editions, music with comments or drawings, and some duplicates. The name(s) of composer(s) and/or arranger(s) and the states and cities where performances were staged are listed when identified. The second subseries, resource material, contains primarily printed music used not only for productions, but also for reference by units and regions throughout the United States.

arrangement.p: Chiefly alphabetically arranged by title of composition within the subject categories: cantatas; music for children; Christmas and Easter presentations; musical revues; operas; oratorios; and additional vocal and instrumental music.
